Award.AwardTitle: RTG: Statistics in the 21st Century - Objects, Geometry and Computing
Award.AbstractNarration:
RTG: Statistics in the 21st Century - Objects, Geometry and Computing

Images, matrices, functions, trajectories, trees, or graphs are examples of objects increasingly encountered in modern data analysis. Statistical analysis of such object data requires skills and knowledge that are not (yet) part of a standard training of a statistician. This includes modern data handling skills, such as accessing web services, or manipulating large data in complex formats; skills needed for working in a multi-disciplinary scientific environment; and also mathematical skills, in particular involving notions of geometry, shape or topology. The project provides training to undergraduate and graduate students, addressing these issues through data analysis applied to important scientific questions, exposure to research in advanced methodologies, corresponding relevant mathematical theories, and computing. Graduate students and postdoctoral fellows also receive training in teaching, mentoring, scientific writing and communication skills, and also in other aspects that are essential for a successful academic career, such as grant writing and job application.

Continuous technological advances go hand in hand with a rapid increase of novel, complex data types, and the importance of developing skills necessary for their analysis cannot be overstated. Aspects of geometry and computing often lie in the center of such an analysis. The project is thus critically advancing training related to the analysis of such modern data types, thereby striving to provide a model for a broad, modern training in statistics. The project builds on the experiences and the strengths of the senior personnel, the affiliated members and collaborators from scientific fields including applied mathematics, astronomy, bio-demography, computer science, and neuroscience. The training activities will not only further strengthen the statistics program at UC Davis, but will also make critical contributions to enhancing the workforce in the STEM disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project provided education and training in modern methods of statistics and data science to undergraduate students, graduate students and postdocs . 

I. Undergraduate training and professional development:  The undergraduate training and professional development activities provided by the RTG consisted of (i) undergraduate research projects; (ii) training for giving oral presentations (RTG Mini-Conference) (iii) holding sessions on "Applying to Graduate School". 

Details: (i) The RTG ran a total of 39 undergraduate research projects with a total of 117 undergraduate participants. Approximately half of the undergraduate participants were female.  There is clear evidence that he RTG program has solidified the anticipated graduate school plans of the particpants, with an average of 75 percent of undergraduate trainees indicating they plan to pursue Master's and an average of 46 percent planning to pursue a Ph.D. in statistics or a related field.  (ii):  The annual research projects went along with presentations of the research outcomes by the undergraduate students at the RTG Mini-Conference. When preparing for this conference, the students were also taugh best practices for conducting oral presentations. The RTG Mini-Conference was broadly advertised. Participating students also invited their friends and family to this highlight to cap the research activities. (iii) Applying to graduate school sessions were held every year. They featured important topics such as: How to obtain letters of recommendations? How to write a strong personal statement? How to prepare for a potential interview? Is a gap-year ok? Should I apply for a Masters or a PhD? Participating students also obtained handouts with information on the indicated topics.

II. Graduate student training and support:  The RTG supported a total of 16 graduate students, 5 of them female. Ten of them have meanwhile graduated (5 PhD, 5 MS). Among those who graduated are three female students (1 PhD, 2 MS), and one of those three females was from an underrepresented group. One of those who have graduated has taken a tenure track Assistant Professorship at the California State University, Sacramento, two others are currently postdocs at Lawrence Livermore National Labs, and at Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center, Seattle, WA, respectively, and one is a lecturer in statistics at UC Davis. Five students are still actively working on their PhD degree, and this includes 2 female students, with one of the females being a URM student. The training activities for graduate students consisted of the following:

Special topics courses/reading groups: A total of 9 quarter-long PhD-level special topics courses and reading groups on relevant topics have been held. RTG graduate student presentations: These presentations were held three times, targeting graduate students from programs other than statistics. The idea was to expose these graduate students to novel statistical and computational methods that they might be able to use for their own research. The presentations were also meant to increase the visibility of statistics, and importantly, they also provided the opportunity for the graduate students to practice their oral presentation and teaching skills. Each presentation was drawing an audience of between 20 and 50 graduate students and researchers from the UC Davis campus. Teaching: The RTG graduate students (except those who graduated with an MS degree) were all teaching classes independently. Most of these classes were classes regularly offered by the Department of Statistics or by the UC Davis Data Studies program. However, two of the RTG students, with support from a faculty member of the Department of Statistics, developed a very successful 10-hour lecture series on Python programming. Mentoring experience: RTG graduate students were part of the undergraduate research projects. They were serving as mentors to the undergraduate students, were helping them with their research, and supported them in preparing their presentations for the RTG Mini-Conference. Teaching material was made available to the public through websites, and research output of the graduate students was (and will be) published in relevant journals.

III. Postdoc training and mentoring: The RTG had one postdoctoral fellow for a total of three years. The postdoc was an integral part of the RTG. He was included in all the RTG activities, he was conducting independent research, and he was a beloved teacher. He also involved in running RTG undergraduate research projects. The experience he gained as a member of the RTG, helped him to secure a position as Lecturer in Statistical Sciences at Baylor University.

IV. Symposia, lecture and seminar series: To support the training and the education of the RTG graduate students and the postdoc, and to contribute to a lively scientific environment, the RTG organized 4 successful interdisciplinary symposia, 4 lecture series, and approximately 20 seminars on topics related to the theme of the RTG.
